posts.name: Jonathan Thomas Miller
posts.cooked: Hey all, I am a high school teacher/ FRC coach. I am beginning to learn programming and am looking to introduce it into my engineering class. My students have almost exclusively chromebooks and am wondering if anyone has suggestions for doing FRC programming with chromebooks as the FRC game tools can’t be loaded onto a chromebook nor can the WPI lib or vs code.

posts.name: Brandon McDonald
posts.cooked:
If you haven’t already try installing WPIlib via the linux download. ChromeOS is a version of linux so this might work Release WPILib 2024.3.2 Release · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub

It is possible to get VS Code on a Chromebook but you may have to take some extra steps. Coding and learning with VS Code on Chromebooks

You may still need another device to deploy code to the robot though.

link_counts.title: Coding and learning with VS Code on Chromebooks

posts.cooked:
There are a few posts floating around on how to use github spaces, you may want to setup one in your teams robot code and use that.

brandonmcd:

You may still need another device to deploy code to the robot though

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
brandonmcd:

You may still need another device to deploy code to the robot though.

And, to be clear, you will need another device to actually enable the robot (in that the driver station software is Windows-only).

If you’ve got a supporter willing to whip out a credit card for about $300, I suggest snagging a business-class laptop off eBay.  (Or ideally, two–one for programmers, one squeaky-clean install for driver station.)  My work daily driver is a Latitude 7420 , and it’s got plenty left in the tank.  But anything in that Latitude/ThinkPad/Elitebook genre that meets modern-enough specs will last you way longer than anything new at Best Buy for the same money.

Here’s the slide from my Kickoff workshop this year:

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: I would also suggest (for the slightly longer term) trying to find a computer supplier/manufacturer as a sponsor. There’s nothing like getting a donation-in-kind of good laptops for your programming team.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Possibly a E-Waste recycling center. They get usable machines donated from companies in batches. When a local college was dumping a bunch of desktops we snagged some for backup PCs in the lab. Might need to put a couple together to get a good machine, but those places might also have stuff already good to go and checked out. I think our PC servicing classes also got machines this way to take apart and learn from

Around us there was a place where the front was a storefront with working machines and equipment and the back where donations and stuff were brought in. They might be willing to part with a laptop that’s been sitting around

posts.name: Fedor Leonov
posts.cooked: Hello! I made a post about coding on a Chromebook (or any device, really) without changing any system settings. You can see my post here . Have a great day!

posts.name: Dkt01
posts.cooked:
You won’t be able to do everything like deploying to robot, running driver station, etc, but you can write code on any web-connected device with GitHub Codespaces .  We added a devcontainer definition to our robot project this year and it’s great for making quick changes or even bigger changes when you don’t want to switch branches/checkout an additional copy of code to your main development PC.

I don’t know about other languages, but for C++, the 4-core container is far more usable than the 2-core container.  We use the wpilib cross-compiling Ubuntu docker image as a base ( wpilib/roborio-cross-ubuntu:2024-22.04 ) and then install a few extensions and formatting utilities to the codespace.

Below are our dockerfile and codespace definition json file if you want to try doing something similar with your codebase.  You can even add a nice badge to make it more clear this is an option to users ( creating an open in github codespaces badge ).

link_counts.title: Facilitating quick creation and resumption of codespaces - GitHub Docs
